image.altText: Several people wheel a stretcher in to a large building. The person on the stretcher is obscured by white sheets.

props.synopsis: Slovakia's Prime Minister Robert Fico has been shot after a government meeting in the city of Handlova. An official has described the 59-year-old's condition as "life-threatening".

title.children: Slovakia's PM shot outside government meeting, official says his condition is 'life-threatening'

image.altText: A man speaking, with bright lights visible near him

props.synopsis: All but the most keen political buffs abroad will be hearing the name Robert Fico for the first time right now, and for all the wrong reasons.

title.children: Assassination attempt on 'polarising' leader Robert Fico came after years of controversy

image.altText: King Island brown thornbill and King Island scrubtit composite image

props.synopsis: Feral cats outnumber two endangered bird species on King Island six to one — but conservationists are hopeful AI-powered poison traps will help keep the birds going.

title.children: There are just dozens of these two bird species left on King Island — and cats outnumber them two to one

image.altText: A composite image of Peter Dutton and Jim Chalmers.

props.synopsis: Power bill rebates aside, the real post-budget debate will likely be over the government's Future Made in Australia plan. This is where Peter Dutton has chosen to fight.

title.children: The Coalition isn't backing the Future Made in Australia plan so far — and it has Labor rubbing their hands together

image.altText: Jim Chalmers stands at the podium of the national press club

props.synopsis: Treasurer Jim Chalmers's latest federal budget includes more than $80 billion of "spending" not on the books. Economists say that's where governments put their "dirty laundry".

title.children: 'Dirty laundry's there': Federal budget includes more than $80 billion of 'spending' not on the books

image.altText: A historical statue cut down and vandalised.

props.synopsis: In the 1860s, there was a "loathsome" rush to collect the bones of Aboriginal Tasmanians. It sparked a shameful saga, centring on unsuspecting Aboriginal man William Lanne, and aspiring politician William Crowther. It echoes to this day – culminating in the toppling of a statue in Hobart.

title.children: William Crowther's statue was toppled in Hobart — why is he such a divisive figure?

image.altText: Dozens of torched cars sit in a carpark as smoke rises in the distance

props.synopsis: Four people have now died in the unrest, with French officials saying a police officer died from a gunshot wound.

title.children: Police officer dies amid New Caledonia riots as France declares a state of emergency

image.altText: Ali Brigginshaw and Jaime Chapman stand next to shield

props.synopsis: New South Wales and Queensland kicks off a historic three-match State of Origin series in Brisbane on Thursday night. Here's everything you need to know.

title.children: Everything you need to  know about State of Origin Game I

image.altText: Nicola, right, looks longingly at Luke, left, who lightly touches her face while outside in the evening.

props.synopsis: The Bridgerton, Derry Girls and Big Mood star graced us with her presence at the week-long PR stunt that recently saw Bowral, NSW, transformed into something intended to resemble regency era England. We still haven't recovered.

title.children: Nicola Coughlan never expected to be the lead in a romance, but she finally is and just, thank god

image.altText: A man sitting in a gaming chair whose faces changes into several different people.

props.synopsis: AI tools such as face-swapping and chatbots are being used by South-East Asia's crime syndicates to make their scams more efficient and effective. However, some operations appear to be having less success with the new tech than others.

title.children: From face-swapping to chatbots — here's how South-East Asia's scammers are using AI tools

image.altText: Michelle Bulang in her kitchen with light pink walls and pie tins in front of her.

props.synopsis: In the Philippines women who are abused by their husband have an even more difficult time leaving. Divorce is not an avenue available to them.

title.children: Michelle's husband beat her and her children. She still can't legally divorce him

image.altText: Lai Ching-te waves while standing behind a lectern.

props.synopsis: The ABC understands up to four MPs will make the journey to Taiwan for the event for Lai Ching-te.

title.children: China's ominous warnings won't stop Australian MPs attending inauguration for Taiwan's new president

image.altText: A male figure skater in a black outfit squats down and holds his foot with his hand as he spins

props.synopsis: The ruling by the US Center for SafeSport bans Kerry for life from any events or activities controlled by the US Olympic and Paralympic Committee.

title.children: Australian Olympic figure skater Brendan Kerry banned by US sport safety body for sexual misconduct

image.altText: A composite image of an older man and an older woman smiling.

props.synopsis: The daughter of Carol Clay tells a Victorian court her mother had a "very loving and caring" relationship with Russell Hill, with whom she was allegedly murdered during a camping trip in 2020.

title.children: Court hears details of Victorian camper's last radio call on night of alleged murder

image.altText: A woman with red short hair in a light blue shirt is in a wheelchair and laughing while in front of a beach outside

props.synopsis: It's Pay Day! Elly Desmarchelier shares the financial reality of living with a disability, why salary-sacrificing her car turned out to be a disaster, and the money advice from her parents that she carries with her to this day.

title.children: Salary sacrificing her car taught Elly two valuable lessons: read the damn contract and plan for the worst

image.altText: Protesters clash outside a Cumberland City Council

props.synopsis: Cumberland City Council has voted to overturn a controversial ban on same-sex parenting books from its libraries after more than four hours of debate.

title.children: Western Sydney council votes to overturn ban on same-sex parenting books in libraries after lengthy debate

image.altText: An illustration of a white balloon floating in front of clouds in the sky.

props.synopsis: Critics line up as Australia's most in-debt state takes its largest venture capitalist gamble yet, betting on a US satellite imagery and space tourism company.

title.children: Victoria launches $37 million gamble on space tourism as critics lament debt balloon

image.altText: A distraught middle-aged man and woman stand in front of a grey curtain

props.synopsis: It's been almost two weeks since Kye Schaefer was fatally stabbed in Coffs Harbour. His parents are calling on the person responsible to be "honest and own up".

title.children: Parents of 21-year-old stabbed to death while heading for a surf issue tearful plea to killer

image.altText: Black snake in ute.

props.synopsis: Newcastle woman Lisa Kournelis has been driving around with a deadly snake in her car for about six weeks. It's not unheard of for snakes to make their way into vehicles, but it is highly unusual for them to linger so long. So why is this one still there?

title.children: Why won't 'Fluffy' the red-bellied black snake leave Lisa's car?

image.altText: A graphic image showing the NDIS logo, a hand on a calculator, and stacks of folders.

props.synopsis: Disability was a big part of this year's federal budget. Here are the key takeaways now the dust has settled.

title.children: From NDIS cost revisions to a new employment program, what's in the budget for disability?

image.altText: Princess Diana with short blonde hair wears a black suit and white pearl necklace with matching earrings and looks off camera.

props.synopsis: The BBC had made false allegations about Steve Davies, resulting in him being fired without cause in 1996.

title.children: Princess Diana's former chauffeur settles slander claim against BBC, nearly 30 years after allegation was made

image.altText: A women with blonde hair tied back into a ponytail looks towards the camera.

props.synopsis: Six deaths that occurred inside a major Tasmanian hospital will now be re-examined by the state coroner — with a nurse and midwife instrumental in bringing on the investigation asking: "Why does it take until nurses speak up, for there to be truth, justice, and accountability?"

title.children: Nurse welcomes investigation into six deaths at major Tasmanian hospital

image.altText: A yellow house with green roof and deck in front.

props.synopsis: The owner of a house where 40 workers from Vanuatu were living dismisses concerns of fire risk at the property, where Tasmanian authorities found 56 beds and conditions described as "poor and unsafe".

title.children: Fire risk 'very significant' in overcrowded Tasmanian house with 40 seasonal workers crammed inside

image.altText: A freight train stopped on the tracks with a white ute on the tracks in front of it.

props.synopsis: A man has a lucky escape after jumping out of his car before it is hit by a train at Devonport, in the state's north-west.

title.children: Man jumps from car before train smashes into it at Tasmanian level crossing

image.altText: Jim Chalmers stands at the podium of the national press club

props.synopsis: With an eye to the next election, Treasurer Jim Chalmers spruiked what he saw as the government's economic achievements in last night's budget speech. But did he stick to the facts?

title.children: We fact checked some key claims from Jim Chalmers's budget speech. Here's what we found

image.altText: ‘An absolute privilege’ Senator Fatima Payman on her politics journey so far

props.synopsis: A federal Labor backbencher has broken ranks to accuse Israel of carrying out "genocide" in Gaza, calling on her party to sanction and cease trade with Israel.

title.children: Labor backbencher breaks ranks to label Gaza invasion a 'genocide'

image.altText: A photo graphic of a blurred-out young male on a mobile phone sitting in front of a laptop.

props.synopsis: For up to four weeks, Alex and his family received up to 50 food deliveries a day after his address was shared by someone he had an argument with while playing Call of Duty online. Here's what to do if, like Alex, you've been doxxed.

title.children: Alex was doxxed while playing Call of Duty. What happened next was a living nightmare for him and his family

image.altText: A red Australia Post electric sign

props.synopsis: The government is warning taxpayers may have to step in to prop up Australia Post, with the federal budget sounding the alarm for the organisation's financial position.

title.children: Taxpayers warned the public may have to prop up Australia Post

image.altText: A person's arms are pictured shaping a heart with its hands, behind it a large round portal in which people in Dublin are seen

props.synopsis: Officials have hit a pause on a video screen called The Portal that lets people in New York and Dublin peer into life on opposite sides of the Atlantic in real time.

title.children: Sidewalk video portal connecting New York and Dublin paused after spectators caught misbehaving on camera

image.altText: A large classical sandstone building with columns

props.synopsis: A former couple charged with numerous child exploitation and sexual abuse offences will have 27 charges withdrawn, while more than 60 other charges remain against the pair.

title.children: Foster parents who allegedly sexually abused children facing more than 60 charges

image.altText: A Qantas plane taxies along a runway in overcast conditions while passengers seated inside watch on.

props.synopsis: The federal government says Australia's intake of migrants will fall sharply — halving in two years — as it overhauls the migration system and moves to reduce pressures caused by population growth.

title.children: Immigration is set to drop sharply, but experts say the government shouldn't claim much credit

image.altText: A composite image of a woman in a black hoodie, a loveheart-shaped pin of two boys, and a third boy in school uniform

props.synopsis: Wendy Elizabeth Chattaway was previously jailed for 12 months for lying to police about her role in a horror crash that claimed the lives of a mother and three children at Yanco near Leeton during 2023.

title.children: Driver involved in crash that killed woman and three children avoids time behind bars

image.altText: a composite image of Heidi Klum, Farhana Bodhi, Greta Gerwig and Jane Fonda

props.synopsis: We're gearing up for a glut of red carpet moments from the south of France in the coming days. Here's a quick recap of the looks we saw at the opening ceremony.

title.children: Cannes Film Festival fashion: Jane Fonda, Meryl Streep, Heidi Klum and a pair of hoof-like shoes
